title: Basohli
summary: Basohli, formerly Vishwasthali, is a town and tehsil located in the Kathua district of Jammu and Kashmir, India, on the right bank of the River Ravi. Founded by Raja Bhupat Pal around 1635, it is renowned for its unique GI-tagged Basohli Paintings, a distinctive style of Pahari miniatures. In the late 17th century, Basohli became a significant center for these paintings, celebrated by Dr. Herman Goltz as "great achievements of Indians." The art is characterized by striking colors, bold lines, and rich symbolism, drawing themes from Vaishnavism, epics, Puranas, and secular life. The town also features the ruins of old palaces and part of the Ranjit Sagar Dam.
key_points: Basohli is a town and tehsil in the Kathua district of Jammu and Kashmir, India, located on the River Ravi.
It was founded around 1635 by Raja Bhupat Pal and is known for its ruined palaces.
Basohli is famous for its unique 'Basohli Paintings', a GI-tagged style of Pahari miniatures.
The Basohli School emerged as a major center for Pahari paintings in the late 17th century.
Basohli paintings are noted for their blazing colors, bold lines, rich symbols, and themes often inspired by Vaishnavism, epics, and Puranas.
The town has an average elevation of 460 meters and includes part of the Ranjit Sagar Dam.

current_status: Basohli is a recognized tehsil and town in Jammu and Kashmir, India, known internationally for its unique GI-tagged Basohli paintings. Its historical palaces are currently in ruins, but the art form continues to be celebrated as a significant achievement of Indian culture, influencing artistic and academic discourse.
future_prospects: Future prospects for Basohli likely involve continued promotion and preservation of its distinctive Basohli paintings, potentially leading to increased cultural tourism and academic interest. Efforts may focus on maintaining the GI tag's integrity, fostering new artistic talent inspired by the Basohli style, and further documenting its rich historical and artistic legacy.
